text: <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> Spi-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and <extra_id_0> C/EBP alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulate expression of the <extra_id_0> granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .
Growth factor receptors play an important role in hematopoiesis .

In order to further understand the mechanisms directing the expression of these key regulators of hematopoiesis , we initiated a study investigating the transcription factors activating the expression of the <extra_id_0> granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .

Here , we demonstrate that the human <extra_id_0> GM-CSF receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter directs reporter gene activity in a tissue - specific fashion in myelomonocytic cells , which correlates with its expression pattern as analyzed by reverse transcription PCR .

The <extra_id_0> GM-CSF receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter contains an important functional site between positions -53 and -41 as identified by deletion analysis of reporter constructs .
We show that the myeloid and B cell transcription factor <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binds specifically to this site .

Furthermore , we demonstrate that a CCAAT site located upstream of the <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> site between positions -70 and -54 is involved in positive - negative regulation of the <extra_id_0> GM-CSF receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity .
<extra_id_0> C/EBP alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is the major CCAAT / enhancer - binding protein ( C / EBP ) form binding to this site in nuclear extracts of U937 cells .

Point mutations of either the <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> site or the C / EBP site that abolish the binding of the respective factors result in a significant decrease of <extra_id_0> GM-CSF receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity in myelomonocytic cells only .

Furthermore , we demonstrate that in myeloid and B cell extracts , <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> forms a novel , specific , more slowly migrating complex ( PU-SF ) when binding the <extra_id_0> GM-CSF receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> site .
This is the first demonstration of a specific interaction with <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on a myeloid <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding site .

The novel complex is distinct from that described previously as binding to B cell enhancer sites and can be formed by addition of <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to extracts from certain nonmyeloid cell types which do not express <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , including T cells and epithelial cells , but not from erythroid cells .

Furthermore , we demonstrate that the PU-SF complex binds to <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> sites found on a number of myeloid promoters , and its formation requires an intact <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> site adjacent to a single-stranded region .
Expression of <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in nonmyeloid cells can activate the <extra_id_0> GM-CSF receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .

Deletion of the amino-terminal region of <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> results in a failure to form the PU-SF complex and in a concomitant loss of transactivation , suggesting that formation of the PU-SF complex is of functional importance for the activity of the <extra_id_0> GM-CSF receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .

Finally , we demonstrate that <extra_id_0> C/EBP alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can also active the <extra_id_0> GM-CSF receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter in nonmyeloid cells .
